GUSTAV VON WANGENHEIM, portraying the character of Hutter stands in front of a mirror tying his neckpiece. He wears early 19th-century German traveling clothes. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

CLOSE ON: GRETA SCHROEDER, portraying the character of El (Hutter's wife), leaning over a windowbox, dangling a pie string above a cat. She wears a 19th century hoop dress a her hair is in long finger-curls. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

Nice pussy. Nice pussy. You're very content right now, aren't you Ellen? You live in a nice house. You wear pretty clothing. And best of all, you're married to a wonderful man who's promised to love you forever. You little suspect that he's about to go on a long journey. And that, when he returns, he'll bring with him the death of love. And your womb will be (MORE )
MURNAU (O.S.) (cont'd) barren and your bed will be cold and in all the world you will be alone.

Same shot. The camera pulls back to reveal that the exter of Hutter's house is, in fact, a film set--a little oasis light--erected in a cavernous, barrel-vaulted studio. And standing in front of it are three men we'll come to k as MURNAU, GRAU, and MULLER. They're wearing lab coats an safety goggles and look more scientists than filmmakers. Everyone waits breathlessly for the director's approval..

And--end Print it! .-.and then flies into action with military precision: striking the set, switching off the phonograph (providing background music), carrying a chair to the director. Who rips off his goggles providing us with our first real at FRIEDRICH WILHELM MURNAU, 33: tall, handsome with red and a distant, preoccupied air he's capable of bringing t intense focus whenever he's concentrating. Which he demonstrates right now by focusing on...
Wolf, have we established pathos? «WOLFGANG MULLER, the photographer: 30s, glasses, a littl retiring. He looks up from where he's dismantling the cam clearly enrapt by MURNAU's attention.
Perfectly, Herr Doctor. In one take.

Good. Get the film to the lab right away. I want to see rushes first thing in the morning before we leave. Albin? ALBIN GRAU, producer and art director, walks over: late thirties, something of an Aesthete.
Yes, Herr Doctor?
Hurry up and strike your set, will you? This Potemkin village is costing our investors a fortune.
Shooting outside the studio will cost them even more.

Such is the price of genius. (shouting) God, save me from all this phony shit! He throws out his arms, accidentally sends a stack of fil tins flying from the hands of MULLER's assistant (PAUL). Everyone freezes. There's a long beat until, oblivious, MURNAU sits, turns to his script. The crew resumes its wo PAUL falls to his knees, scrambles to pick up the tins.
I'm sorry, Herr Doctor.
Was there something wrong with the set, Friedrich?

No, I'm anxious to get out of here, that's all. But I do need your inventory for the trip. Alsoa complete itinerary and a scene break-— down by costume and set. Speaking of which, I looked over your renderings last night for the last scene in Ellen's bedroom. I think they'll be fine.
High praise, Herr Doctor.
We'll need blueprints, of course, and photos for when we finally get round to building it on Helgoland. And there was something else...oh yes, the cat was sluggish.

Jesus, Albin. What's wrong with you? Take the damned thing out and have it shot. We look over to see HENRIK GALEEN, the screenwriter: 30s scholarly. He's sitting on packing crate, a sheaf of manu scripts spread across his lap.
Henrik, I hope we're not going to be out in the field without enough copies of your script.
No, Friedrich. The brothers of the monastery are putting the gold leaf on them now.

(ignoring him, shouting) Hurry up, ladies and gentlemen! We have a train to catch! He turns back to his script, a steel door is opened, the and noise of 1921 Berlin pour in. Enter GRETA wearing a dressing gown and smoking a cigaret an ivory holder. Without her wig and make-up she seems dangerously young and beautiful, perhaps seventeen.
Nicely done, Greta. For a moment I even thought I saw a premonition of evil cross your face.
(sitting beside him) It wouldn't surprise me. With all the spooky shit you've been saying to me. On-camera and off.
I told you, it's important for the realistic effect.
Yes, I know all about it. That's why we're being forced to pack up and go...what do you call this business again?
"On-location..."
"On-location." To Transylvania.
Actually, we're not going to Transylvania. We're going to Slovakia.
Herr Doctor, I believe one is supposed to call it Czechoslovakia now.
Yes, yes. Czechoslovakia.
But why do we have to leave Berlin just now? At the start of the theater season?
(ignoring her) Albin, has your man arranged the cars?
Yes. Two.
Do you have any idea the parts I've been offered at long last? The salaries?
Will that be enough?
It'll have to be. It's probably every car in the region.
Good.
Herr Doctor, you're ignoring me. (seductively) There was a time when you didn't ignore me...

Honestly, Greta, why would anyone care to act in a play when they had the opportunity to act in a film? As GRETA continues, a sordid-looking man in an ambulance driver's coat (a red cross on his sleeve) comes up and whispers something to MURNAU.

You certainly didn't think that when you were directing plays for Reinhardt. In any case, I don't like acting for the camera. A theatrical audience gives you life, while this thing... (indicating the camera) .-.-merely takes it from you. MURNAU turns sharply, takes her hand. Like MULLER before she responds rapturously.

(softly, confidently) Listen to me, Greta. I conceived this role especially for you. Ellen isa woman who discovers the ultimate expression of love in the most exquisite pain imaginable. Sound familiar? It will be your most demanding role. The role that will make you great as an actress. Consider it a sacrifice to your art. He stands, follows the sordid-lcooking man outside. She watches him, turns--a little embarrassed--to the others..
(recovering) I'm already being paid peanuts. ..-exits. GALEEN watches her go, turns to GRAU.
So what'd you give the cat?
Chloral.
Chloral!
It's hard to keep the damn things docile under the lights. Did it show?
It looked pickled.
Not so much as Greta.  MURNAU returns. Looks at his pocketwatch.
Almost dark. Well, everything here seems to be in hand...
Friedrich, we still need to talk about the vampire.
No, no...it's nearly dark. I'm already late. Wrap things up for me here, will you Albin? I'll see you all in the morning. MURNAU jogs to the door... ---exits.
(shouting after him) But what costume should I pack for him? What make-up?
It doesn't matter. And be sure that imbecile Gustav doesn't miss the train.
Where's he running off to?
Perhaps he has a woman.
(meaningfully) Or a man. They smile knowingly at this. Then, jokingly:
Did you notice how concerned he was whether or not it was after dark?
Perhaps our director is the vampire.

MURNAU climbs into his car, the chauffeur shuts the door, behind the wheel, drives away. We follow it through downt Berlin as the sun sets on sidewalks clotted with blind be and legless war veterans. As they come upon the crowded entrance of a chic cabaret.
«..the chauffeur turns to MURNAU...
Front or back, Herr Doctor?
Back, of course.

«».-and then steers into a dark alley where the car's hea lights illuminate a knot of pretty boys in army fatigues languidly congregating outside an unmarked door. MURNAU climbs out, raps on the door, is permitted inside. Then the door shuts behind him, his car drives off, and t illicit scene is plunged into darkness again.
Dark and smoky, echoing with Dixieland, populated by characters out of George Grosz: millionaires, whores, etc MURNAU passes through the crowd, climbs the stairs to an.

where--lying on a settee, watching the throng below--we discover a breathtaking young woman (MICHELINE): late tee pale skin, black hair, a very revealing flapper dress. MURNAU bares his teeth, jumps on her, buries his face in throat. She moans in pleasure, turns her face away, sucks smoke out of a cigarette holder.
Herr Doctor, I have a pain.  10. He lifts one of her legs, slowly peels back the dress and kisses the place where her rolled stocking reveals her th
Does that feel better?
Are you really a doctor?

Yes. Of philosophy. She smiles lewdly at him, then suddenly scissors him betw her legs, flips him over onto the settee, climbs on top. Slaps him playfully. And then does it harder. MURNAU smil surrenders to her: now he's the one who's rapturous. We look down toward the stage: performing a torch song fo the corpse-faced Berliners is a large-busted woman in an evening gown. With bat's wings.

De Stijl furniture, Die Briicke murals, etc. MURNAU is pa ing by candlelight when MICHELINE--half naked, smoking a cigarette in a holder--appears behind him. Weirdly, her entrance causes a few of the candles blow out.
Friedrich, do you have to go?
I'll be back in six or eight weeks.
What shall I do without you?
Operate your cabaret. Dream of my return.
Won't you at least tell me what it is you're filming?
Not this time. It's a surprise...
I hate surprises.  11.
«--a@ surprise for you. A film all about a woman like you... MURNAU stops what he's doing, takes her in his arms.
«--who sacrifices everything for her lover. MICHELINE grabs him by the throat...
And you think I would ever do such a thing? That's a rather skewed characterization coming from a man I've spent the past two hours raping like a woman. .«-.shoves him roughly away.
Still, I must admit you took it like a man.
You're the only one I've ever allowed to treat me that way.
I don't doubt it... (pointedly) «..-Herr Doctor. Now tell me more about your movie.
No. You'll see when it's finished. Now, have you eaten?
I want to eat you.
You're not serious.
But I am... She grabs him, pulls him into...  12.
«-.throws him onto the bed, climbs on top of him.
Now kiss me good-bye, Friedrich. It's time that I was going.
Why won't you ever stay the night?
I've told you: if I'm not back to count the night's receipts my staff will bleed me dry.
Stay. She stands, rests her shoe on his lower lip.
Beg.
Please stay. You love me, don't you?
What do you think?
Say it.
No.
Why not? I love you. She looks at him imperiously. Lightly slaps his face with toe of her shoe.
That, Herr Doctor, is a very dangerous thing to say. Nevertheless, she kicks off her shoes, curls up beside hi He smiles contentedly, reaches up, turns out the light.  13.
Enter Hutter with flowers. He kisses his wife good-bye. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)
Later. MICHELINE, a long cape over her dress, emerges fro MURNAU's Bauhaus-style building. Hurries away.

The crew of Nosferatu loads boxes onto one of the trains the watchful eye of GALEEN, GRAU, and MULLER. Suddenly there's a disturbance 0.S. and MURNAU--lapels pu up, hat pulled down--hurries up followed by porters and a of newspaper reporters. He grabs PAUL.
You work for me don't you?
Yes, Herr Doctor.
Then get my things. Albin? As PAUL begins directing the porters, MURNAU turns to GRA
Tell them nothing. «then leaps onto the train. GRAU faces the reporters.
Gentlemen, I am Albin Grau. Producer and art director of this picture.
Where's Murnau?  14.
Is it true Murnau is filming Stoker's Dracula?

Friedrich Wilhelm Murnau is Germany's greatest filmmaker--in a class with such masters as Griffith and Eisenstein. At present he is supervising every detail of this unique on-location expedition. Exactly how unique you'll discover when the picture premieres in Berlin. And at that time, I'm certain you'll be convinced beyond the shadow of a doubt of the exceptional talent of this remarkable genius. The reporters clamor for more, GRAU climbs onto the train
You did that quite well, Albin.

In the future I think there might actually be a living to be made from this sort of thing. Representative to the press. The last of the luggage is brought aboard, a whistle blow people make their farewells, the train pulls out of the..
«+.roars out of the city.
CLOSE ON: MURNAU asleep. The door opens, MULLER peeks in. Sees MURNAU sleeping, closes it again.
MULLER moves down the corridor to the...  15.

where he finds the rest of the crew at lunch: GRAU, GALEE and PAUL (met earlier) and three young women: ELKE (cos- tumes), MARIA (script), and EVA (make-up). MULLER enters, sits. Tosses a rolled-up map to GRAU...
Still asleep?
Yes. Must have been quite a night.
Albin, let's see the map. .-.who clears off a place on the steamer trunk acting as table and unrolls a large map of Central/Eastern Europe.

We'll cross the border into Czechoslovakia in a few hours at the foothills of the Carpathians and continue until the line ends at Oravska Magura. From there we'll go by automobile to a place near Poprad in the Vysoke Tatry: the High Tatra Mountains
Apparently Herr Doctor's already filmed some of the exteriors there.
He has?
You didn't know?
No.
That's odd. Anyway, you can assume we'll be filming all of Hutter's scenes there: the carriage scenes, the scenes at the inn with the superstitious natives...  Enter GUSTAV 16.
«..the scenes between him and the vampire.
I still don't understand why we're not going to Tranyslvania.
Yes, everyone knows Count Dracula lives in Transylvania.
Strictly speaking, this isn't Dracula. The author's widow refused to sell us the rights to the novel. She's hoping to prepare a stage version to open in London.
Bound to make more money than any film.
Which is all very interesting, Henrik. But it doesn't address the larger question.
Which is?
Who's playing our vampire? VON WANGENHEIM, the actor portraying Hutter.
His name is Schreck.
Schreck?
Max Schreck. Apparently he was in the Reinhardt company. Did you know him, Albin?
Schreck? Are you sure you have the name right? "Schreck" is dialect for "shriek." What, did he specialize in fright roles?  17.
Just a character actor. Max Schreck.
Who told you he was playing the vampire?
Herr Doctor told me.
I didn't know any Max Schreck in the Reinhardt company.
Herr Doctor told me he studied with Stanislavsky in Moscow.
I'm surprised I've never heard of him.
He's from the Russian school then?

Yes. As part of his preparation, he submerges his own personality in that of the character he's portraying. That's the reason he's not traveling with us. Herr Doctor told me went on to Czechoslovakia weeks ago--in order to absorb the flavor of the place, I suppose.
God, you don't think he's been sleeping in a coffin?
Herr Doctor also told me that, once we arrive and begin filming, Max will never appear to us except in full costume and make-up...
A rather extreme interpretation of Stanislavsky, if you ask me. Why wasn't I told about this?
-.-and that furthermore we'll film him only at night.  18.
Why wasn't I told about that?
(looking out the window) There are the Carpathians. Our first sunset in...what's the script say, Henrik?
"The country of blocd-red mountains."
The sun sets behind the train as it races into the dense forests of Eastern Europe.
Later. The corridor is packed with sleeping peasants.
Everyone is nodding off except for GRAU who casts, on the steamer trunk, tarot cards: the fool, death, the ten of swords. Suddenly the door opens. Enter MURNAU.
I see we're knee-deep in peasants.
When did you wake up?
(sitting) The Czech guard woke me at the border. What have you been doing?
Actually we've been talking about you.
Your previously shot footage, your heretofore unannounced additions to the acting company...
As the producer of this film, Herr Doctor, I feel I have a responsibility (MORE )
MURNAU leans MURNAU looks 19. GRAU (cont'd) to ask if there's anything else you've neglected to tell us.
Why? What do the cards say?
Someone close to us will be going on a long journey. Now answer my question. forward conspiratorially.
Look, I confess: there are things I haven't told you about this production. But they'll all be revealed in the course of time.
But how do you expect us to do our jobs when we're kept in the dark? at them, turns his intense focus on his crew-- especially GRAU. They hang on his every word. Suddenly the

Exactly. Let me explain something to you. I intend ours to be the most realistic movie ever made. And what is realism? The unexpected. That's why I took all of you out of the studio and thrust you into the world. So that you'll be forced to react spontaneously to whatever you encounter there. And because of it, Nosferatu will not be just another filmed stage play. It will bea truthful record of reality. And that is what will make it great.
But this is a fiction. A movie about a vampire. How can you talk about realism when the subject is so far removed from reality?
My sense of style is realism. But my sense of art is moral. I want to explore evil with the eye of a scientist. train jolts to a stop.  20.
What's that? Why are we stopping? GRAU reaches over to the window, opens the blind, looks o Then he looks back at the others in awe.
My god...

CLOSE ON: the water reservoir being lowered onto the trai boiler (evidently this is why the train stopped). We pull back and up to see the passengers disgorging from the ste train (for a smoke, to stretch their legs, etc.) and then see what it is that inspired such awe in GRAU:

From above: A vast, impenetrable forest lining the edges the railroad track like an enormous black curtain. On the ground: We follow MURNAU, GRAU, GALEEN, and MULLER they walk through the trees in silent wonder. Until:
The forest primeval. It grows thicker as we move east towards the Tatras.
How do expect me to film in there?
We could use an aeroplane.
You're the pilot, Herr Doctor--at least you were in the last war. But I doubt even a low-flying Fokker could see into it.

There's no place on earth like it. None of it's been thoroughly mapped. Whole armies have marched in never to be heard from again. And then there are the...animals--strange things which by all rights should be extinct. MURNAU, lost in thought, continues along by himself while catch up with...  21.
and the rest the crew (ELKE, EVA, MARIA) walking along th the woods. EVA stops to pick up a pine cone, walks a litt distance by herself. And then stops. Her eyes opening wid in horror...
..-her scream echoing through the trees before it's swall up again by the forest. Hearing it, the train crew grab lamps, hurry in her direc followed by some of the peasants and the rest of the...

..-film crew (except for MURNAU) who, following the lamps make their way through the thick tangle of undergrowth: GALEEN in the lead, MULLER taking up the rear. When suddenly the latter is caught up short when somethin grabs him by the throat. And yanks him into the darkness without a sound.

A few moments later, the search party emerges from the wo carrying EVA's body. They set it down near the tracks, be examining the body by lamplight while a few peasant women gather around, speak softly in Slovak. One of the things we hear them they say is..."nosferatu." Hearing it, GALEEN looks at the other members of the film crew. And that's when MURNAU emerges from the woods, hurr to the body, pushes everyone else away.

Get away from her. She's my responsibility. Somebody produces a sheet, MURNAU himself wraps her body then supervises the others as they load it onto the train like a ghost, through the steam. Then the whistle blows, the remaining people climb onboar  22.

We follow GRAU down the corridor--past the crew cabin (wh the dispirited crew take their seats), past peasants clut ching their rosaries and scribbling crosses everywhere--t door (without a cross). He knocks gently, opens it.
A little light from the corridor reveals MULLER in bed.
Wolf, are you alright?
(dazed) Uh-huh.
Wolf, I...sorry to wake you. Good night. And then door closes, taking with it the light.

The train jerks to a stop waking the sleeping (under coat blankets) crew. They stir. PAUL opens the window shade. Beneath an overcast sky, a small procession passes carrie EVA's enshrouded body. Revealing behind them: MURNAU, standing beside a pair of touring cars. Paying off some k of police official.

A gabled building at the foot of the looming Tatras. The place is deserted except for the pall bearers and the fil erew--the latter loading the cars with equal solemnity. GALEEN walks up to MURNAU as EVA is loaded onto a horse c
They'll put her on the next train back to Berlin. I've sent a telegram to her parents.
What do we do now, Herr Doctor?  23. Beat. All eyes turn to MURNAU.
We go on.
As the last of the passengers disembark, PAUL stops at MULLER's door. Knocks.
Herr Muller? No answer. He knocks again.
Herr Muller? The door opens slowly as if by itself. And we see MULLER, bundled to the gills, sitting at the window: gaunt, dark rings under his eyes.
As the crew prepares to depart, a little boy hands MURNAU wooden cage. MURNAU gives him a coin, the boy runs away.
What's that? MURNAU holds up the cage: rats.
Rats? There aren't any rats called for in the script until the ghost ship: the vampire's disembarkation at Bremen.
They're for mood, Henrik. At the castle. The train whistle blows and it pulls out of the station. Revealing MULLER standing, nonplussed, on the opposite si
Wolf! MULLER turns, walks slowly towards them.  24.
Wolf, what's the matter with you? MULLER climbs silently into one of the cars followed by MURNAU, GALEEN, and PAUL. The others climb into the other one, drive up alongside.
You take the rats! He throws the cage into MURNAU's car which takes the lead the cars disappear into the forest, we remain behind for a moment with the cart with the corpse.
The cars follow the heavily shaded road into the mountain
Think there's anything to eat? GUSTAV roots around in the boxes in the back. He opens on packed with straw. Digs out a bottle filled with blood.
What in hell is this?
My god, it's blood. It must be part of the make-up.
Don't you think you can carry realism too far?

As the sun sets over the mountains behind them, the cars emerge from the forest and stop in front of a large stone cottage with an attached stable. A large white cross has whitewashed on the thatched roof of the building. They begin unloading equipment, the INNKEEPER marches out
Good evening, Herr Doctor! «--and directs them inside.  25.
Long wooden tables, a large hearth providing the only lig Seeing the crew, a couple of old women at their beads interrupt their prayers, begin setting out crockery, etc.
(to the Innkeeper) I wonder if I might be shown to my room.
You're not eating, Wolf? But he ignores him, follows the INNKEEPER upstairs. MURNA sits at one of the tables, examines his script. The other sit with him, begin eating.
Does he seem ill to you?
He's just tired. (to Murnau) What's on the schedule for tomorrow?
Exterior shots of the inn. The arrival of Hutter in the carriage. Some shots in here.
Where are the extras?
(indicating the old woman) You're looking at them.
These people can't act.
They don't need to act. They're playing themselves.
Speaking of actors, I expected to meet Schreck here.
You'll meet Max when his time comes in the shooting schedule.  26. A little woman with a candle enters the main room and the leads them, one at a time, up a narrow, angular staircase
At the top of the staircase is a little hall with doors leading to the bedrooms.
Sleep well everyone. The call is for dawn. They all wish MURNAU a respectful good-night. Then he goe into his room, shuts the door behind him.
A bed, a little table with a candle. Illuminating walls festooned with crosses--some real, some painted. He shive and then...
-.-from outside: we watch him put out the candle. From 0. we hear squealing, and see...
squirming in the cage in the back seat of one of the cars The door closes, the engine turns over, and...
pulls away from the inn.
We follow it as it drives through the dark forest. The ti dirge begins, grows louder as the sequence progresses.

The car emerges in a moon washed clearing high in the mountains. It stops, the driver climbs out. Takes somethi from the back seat. Plunges back into the trees.  27. We follow him until he comes to a gaping, vine-clogged ca He hesitates for a moment, goes inside.

The cave turns out to be a series of Christian catacombs. follow the figure past the primitive symbols cut into its black walls until he stops in front of a dark niche. Then he gingerly sets down the cage containing the rats, hurries back out. As the music grows very loud...
appears: marble white with fu manchu nails. They wrap lik spiders around the cage. Withdraw with it into the dark.

A scaffold has been erected leading to GUSTAV's second fl window. On top of it sits the camera/tripod operated by MULLER and PAUL--both wearing goggles and lab coats. 0O.S phonograph spins background music.
The sun rises. Hutter, in bed, wakes. (Recreated from Nosferatu.)

All right, Hutter. It's been a fitful night. You dreamed that a jackal frightened away the horses and left you stranded hundreds of miles from your beloved wife. But you're a modern man. Aman of science. You wake refreshed, eager to continue your journey to the castle of the nobleman who may very well make your fortune.
in goggles and lab coat, is standing at the door to GUSTA room. Beside him stands GALEEN, at his feet sits ELKE.  28.
What's that beside your bed? Pick it up. It's that ridiculous book from the night before. The book about vampires.
GUSTAV in bed, MULLER at the window, GRAU out of sight of camera, MURNAU at the door. Since the last time we saw th room, all the crosses have been stripped from its walls.

Now you remember. The superstitious peasants put it there. The ones who warned you not to visit Orlock's castle, who warned you not even to speak his name--nosferatu, the unclean, the undead--lest you evoke the creature itself. The INNKEEPER'S WIFE peeks in from the hall behind MURNAU
What I'd like to know is: do all the rooms contain this book? Sort of the Transylvanian version of the Gideon's Bible?
And--end. Henrik, please don't spoil the mood. Wolf, did you get that?
Herr Doctor...
(ignoring her) Wolf...
I'm sorry Herr Doctor, but...
(exasperated) Albin, deal with the natives... GRAU takes the INNKEEPER'S WIFE out into the hall.
Wolf!  29.
(distracted, quietly) The shot was perfect, Friedrich.
What's gotten into you?
Herr Muller slept poorly again last night.

Your name is Paul, isn't it? Please pack one of the cars as I instructed. You and you... (indicating Maria and Elke) «-ehelp him. Then you can all take the rest of the afternoon off. Not you, Gustav. Take an hour for lunch and then get into your traveling costume. Albin, is the carriage ready? Albin? He looks around angrily, charges into the...
where GALEEN, GRAU, and the INNKEEPER'S WIFE are talking. GRAU, smoking a cigarette, seems especially annoyed.
What the hell has gotten into every- one?
She's worried about the crosses.
Why am I being bothered with this?
(to the Innkeeper's Wife) We'll put them back. They just over- whelm the composition.
I told you, Herr Grau, they are not for decoration. You should be more concerned about such things. And you should be more cautious than to leave here at night.  30.
What are you talking about?
Every night someone takes one of your... She mimes turning a steering wheel.
Do you know anything about this, Albin?
No. Where would anyone go?
Henrik, check the petrol. GALEEN hurries out. MURNAU pokes his head back into...
The crew is packing up equipment, replacing the crosses,
Has anyone been driving the cars at night? Everyone says no.
Wolf? Wolf? MULLER, staring blankly toward the mountains, turns angri
What do you want from me, Friedrich? I haven't taken your fucking car. MURNAU looks at him hard. Exits.
GALEEN is inspecting the cars. MURNAU emerges from the in
Well, the tanks are definitely lower than when we arrived.  31.
Do you think the locals might be going for a joyride? GALEEN shrugs.
Well, do you think this will be a problem? GRAU steps out of the stable leading a pair of horses harnessed to a small carriage.
Only you can answer that, Herr Doctor. When will we meet our vampire?
Soon..
As the sun sets over the forest... (Actual footage from Nosferatu.)

.«.-GUSTAV (as Hutter) walks along the side of a hill, pa an icon mounted in a little wooden shrine. (Recreated from Nosferatu.) We pull back to reveal MURNAU, GRAU, and GALEEN standing beside the car while MULLER films the scene.
All right, Hutter. This is the icon the locals have erected to mark the boundary between the land of the living and the land of the dead. Look at it...and walk on. He does, walks out of the frame.
And--end!
Thank god, I'm starving.  32.
There's food in the car. We're not going back just yet. As GUSTAV breaks out a wicker picnic basket...
Where're we going, Friedrich?
You'll see.
It's nearly dark. I can't do a night shoot. Not alone.
I had your equipment packed for you, Wolf. Albin will assist you. It's important that very few of us are present for this.
I suppose we're reaching for the spontaneous effect you spoke of on the train. MULLER packs up his equipment, the others--still eating-- climbing into the car.
Incidentally, I hope everyone has their papers. Just in case.
